import Mathlib

theorem tele (n : ℝ) :
      ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1) =
      5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by
    calc ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1)
      _ = (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) -
          (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1)                       := by rw [mul_sub]; linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) +
          5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by rw [add_mul]; linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n) + (1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by rw [Real.rpow_add]; linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by sorry

      _ = (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) -
          (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1)                       := by rw [mul_sub]; linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) +
          5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by rw [add_mul]; linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by linarith
      _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n) + (1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by rw [Real.rpow_add]; linarith

        rw [← add_halves (1/2^(n-1))]

        field_simp

import Mathlib

theorem temp (n: ℝ): ((1: ℝ) / 2 ^ n) = 2 ^ (- n) := by
  field_simp; rw [<- Real.rpow_add]; ring_nf; norm_num

theorem tele (n : ℝ) :
      ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1) =
      5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by
    ring_nf; field_simp
    rw [temp, temp, <- Real.rpow_two, <- Real.rpow_mul (by norm_num)]
    nth_rewrite 2 [<- Real.rpow_one 2]
    rw [<- Real.rpow_add (by norm_num)]; ring_nf

@spamegg A few lines shorter (building on the solutions provided by others):

import Mathlib
example (n : ℝ) : ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1) = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by
  calc ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1)
    _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) * 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by linarith
    _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n) + (1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1 := by rw [Real.rpow_add]; linarith
    _ = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by
      congr
      rw [Real.rpow_sub_one (by norm_num)]
      field_simp
      norm_num

import Mathlib

example (n : ℝ) : ((5 : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) + 1) * (5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (2^n)) - 1) = 5 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 2^(n-1)) - 1 := by
  rw [← sq_sub_sq, ← Real.rpow_mul_natCast (by norm_num), Real.rpow_sub_one (by norm_num)]
  simp [inv_mul_eq_div]

Great golfing, Aaron! It’s much shorter now, but it also increases the number of referenced named lemmas. Do you think it could be done with fewer than two named lemmas, without significantly increasing the line count compared to the previous solutions?

By the way, is there a recognized term for a style of “golfing” that focuses on maximizing readability—favoring high-level tactics over explicit references to low-level lemmas—rather than simply minimizing lines of code?
I would argue that my version is more readable - it certainly looks better than a wall of calc and you can tell what the lemmas are just from their names.

On the other hand, without the wall of calc, if any of these theorems change, no one has any idea what the intended rewrites were. I've done my share of mathlib maintenance, and it's no fun having to have multiple mathlibs open and carefully checking intermediate proof states.

We tend to over-golf mathlib, confusing short proofs for some kind of efficiency. It's supposed to be that golfing is for obvious facts for which no one is expected to read the details. I think it's more-or-less "things that should be doable by a high-powered tactic, but maybe we don't have that tactic yet."

@Aaron Liu I wasn’t suggesting your answer was less readable: I was just curious about whether it’s possible to use fewer than two lemmas (perhaps it isn't!), and whether there’s a specific term for “lemma golfing” (unrelated to your solution). Sorry for any confusion!
Of course, it is possible, but is it a good idea?

It is technically possible of course (one could re-implement the no longer referenced lemmas by "inlining" them in the proof...), but I meant without increasing the LOC significantly. Is that possible?
Yes, we should aim for readable, maintainable proofs, and we hope we can write "higher-level" proofs that don't need to refer to specific "low-level" lemmas.

It was pretty disappointing in my proof that after congr;field_simp I had it down to (1+1)*2^(n-1)=2^n and it took two more lines to finish. A schoolchild could have done it from there and we didn't seem to have have one tactic which could nail it.

Two more things here:

  • If the point is to write Lean-checked human-readable "paper proofs", the calc seems more appropriate. (In this case, I imagine running through the algebra would be for some pedagogical purpose.)
  • If that's not the objective, where this is in the realm of obvious algebra, a golfed proof might be fine since a tactic should be able to do it automatically. (But, that should be weighed carefully, since it can make maintenance harder. The supposedly efficient proof can tie up a whole lot of maintenance time that the more verbose proof never would have, making it more costly overall.)

Human readability is what we care about in the end, isn't it? If a proof is readable by a human without diving into Lean Infoview, then a human will be able to maintain it. If something breaks, you just recreate that part of the proof.
As a maintainer I would argue that easy maintainability is what I care about in the end.

I had the thought yesterday "What if Mathlib were written by enterprise Java developers? How many lines would it be instead?" (In a former life, I worked on a 5 million line piece of software for hospitals, written in Java. In that environment, even expressions with nested function calls are treated with suspicion, and nearly every intermediate value gets a variable with its own type. Nothing is implicit.) Our 1.8 million lines probably would be nearer to 10 million I'd guess. Maybe some people would estimate 20 million or more.

This doesn't make things more readable though. I found it to be a lot of context you had to keep track of. There's something to be said for being a lot more terse, since you can see everything at once and reason about it. (For extremely terse, see the APL family of language, and Arthur Whitney's K, which somehow is used in finance.)

I don't care at all about the human-readability of calculations such as the above because I am with mathematica on this one -- the argument is totally trivial and of no interest. I just want to make sure that the proof doesn't break later on.
